segments.question: This is a United States Holocaust Memorial Museum interview with Mrs. Goldie Buch Jonas, on May 5", 2013, in Brooklyn, New York. Thank you Mrs. Jonas for agreeing to meet with us today, for agreeing to tell your story, and we will start at the beginning. So I’d like you to tell me when you were born, your date of birth, where you were born, and your name at birth.
segments.answer: Okay, I was born in January 17, 1928, and it was Radéw, Poland. My name is Golda Buch, my maiden name. And that’s as far as I remember my birth, and being — I mean, growing up — excuse me, growing up with two brothers older than I, and my father —

segments.question: Tell me — okay, excuse me.
segments.answer: —my mother.

segments.question: Tell me their names and when they were born.
segments.answer: My oldest brother was Pinhaus(ph) Buch. He was born in 1923, I don’t remember the date. And my middle brother was born in 1925, in July of 1925. Also in the same town as myself in Poland, and we all attended — later on we attended I —a grade school, which 1s in Polish, you know [speaks Polish]. Every — every Jewish child, no matter what religion they was, Orthodox, or very Orthodox, had to attend seventh grade in Polish school. And if the parents could allow themselves, Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas : May 5, 2013 they also sent the children to Hebrew schools, and that’s where I attended after public school; after lunch from one to five, we attended Hebrew school.

segments.question: So you had a long day.
segments.answer: And — yes. And also my brothers attended, learning everything, Judaism and religious and every — we were religious, we were very Orthodox at home. But the kids, you know, my father was [indecipherable] he is sending his boys, his sons to learn whatever is needed to be learned, until the war broke out.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: I finished my fourth grade just in 1939, and we also finished some of the Hebrew school, not everything, because the war started. And then the Germans came in —

segments.question: Hang on a minute, hang on a minute.
segments.answer: Okay.

segments.question: We'll get there. But in the beginning I’d like to ask you many more questions about your childhood, about growing up, about pre-war life. So —
segments.answer: Like what?

And they all did get married in Rozwadow.

segments.question: So —
segments.answer: The siblings of my mother, and the siblings of my father.

segments.answer: My father’s birthday?

segments.question: And would you say that your family was well-to-do, or —
segments.answer: Middle class.

segments.question: Middle class.
segments.answer: Middle class. Not well-to-do, but middle class.

segments.question: Uh-huh. And your father was in the shoe business?
segments.answer: No, my grandfather was in the shoe business. My father was going — when I already knew what he was doing. First he work with his father, of course, then he got married. And then he was going — I don’t know how you call it, he adjust the top of the shoes.

segments.question: Ah, not the soles, but the uppers.
segments.answer: Not the whole shoe. Upper.

segments.answer: Only the upper, the leather, whatever —

segments.question: Yeah. Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas ° May 5, 2013
segments.answer: — 1s needed for winter, for summer. And he developed his own business. My mother, of course, helped him when there was the season. And he had customers coming from the villages every Tuesday to order, you know, whatever they needed for their stores or for their families, whatever. My father worked very hard. And then, I grew up like every child, you know. Happy, hel —

segments.question: Were you the youngest?
segments.answer: I was the youngest. I had friends, I was going to school, I was going to Hebrew school. Never have time too much to be outside like running around or whatever, because my father made sure that we should get whatever education we — we can.

segments.question: So your father emphasized education.
segments.answer: Yeah, this was his first thing.

segments.question: Was he himself educated?
segments.answer: As far as I know, he finished high school.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: So did my mother, but this was al-already in — not in Polish time, this was in [indecipherable] time. That was under ger — under Austrian occupation.

segments.question: Ah, I wou — I was gon —
segments.answer: And th — before the — the first war.

segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: I wanted to know where is Rozwadow in Poland. Is it in the west, 1n the center
segments.answer: It’s in Galicia.

segments.question: It’s in Galicia?
segments.answer: Galicia belonged to Austria, and then they gave it back to Poland —

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: — after the war in 1918.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: After the war finished. It was actually Poland before, but then occupied as Prince Joseph, the King of Austria, he occupied the all Galicia, all the Ukraine, until the liberation of the first war, and then was Poland again.

segments.question: Did your parents talk about the first World War —
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: — and any experiences they might have?
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: No.
segments.answer: No, they never did.

segments.question: They never did. Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas " May 5, 2013
segments.answer: I have never talked to my children about what I went through.

segments.question: What was life like at home? Was it — was your father and mother, were they strict, were they —
segments.answer: Well, he — he wanted the boys, mostly the boys to be very religious and have a good education, as far as he could afforded to pay for it.

segments.question: And your mother, what was she —
segments.answer: My mother was [indecipherable] she raised the children, she made whatever she could clothes. She was sewing clothes for myself, not for my brothers, just for me. She had a sister-in-law, which was a terrific dressmaker, so she used to cut material, and my mother used to sew it. So I always had nice clothes to go to school, or to go to friends, or as you could see from the picture, I was dressed like a middle class person, like a middle class child actually.

segments.question: Was a middle class child in Poland, a middle class family, the same thing as in the United States?
segments.answer: No, poorer.

segments.question: Poorer. Poorer.
segments.answer: Much poorer.

segments.question: Okay. Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas " May 5, 2013
segments.answer: A middle class family — I consider my son middle class, but we never could afforded what he has here, never.

segments.question: Okay, did your parents own your own home — their own home?
segments.answer: They owned an apartment, yes, which consisted of two rooms and a kitchen. And of course a yard, and — and also [indecipherable] shed where they kept, you know, stuff for the winter. And —

segments.question: Did you have animals?
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: Like no horses, no —
segments.answer: No, no.

segments.question: Nothing like that.
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: Did you have a ma — an automobile?
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: How large was Rozwadow” Was it a big town?
segments.answer: The apartment are big?

segments.question: No, no, the town. Rozwadow. Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas " May 5, 2013
segments.answer: The town — we had — the town was not big, but it was a 90 percent Jewish town, with a lot of youth. We had our own Buirgermeister, which means the mayor was a Jew, a very rich Jew. And we had a city hall, we had a jail. No hospitals, we had doctors, we had pharmacists, and of course a lot of merchants.

segments.question: So, it was a large Jewish community.
segments.answer: A large Jewish community, yes.

segments.question: Within a small town, would that — or was it a city?
segments.answer: Well, the town was not big, but you cannot consider a very small town.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: We had three shuls.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: In the three, we had a — the very Orthodox shul; we had the Conservative, more or less, shul; and we had — and the rabbis, of course, had their own shuls. There were four rabbis in our town. There were two brothers, and they had their own shuls, with their own people who went to them, just there.

segments.question: Did —
segments.answer: To pray, I mean.

segments.question: Yeah. Did everybody know each other, or not really? Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas : May 5, 2013
segments.answer: Well, mostly like families know — knew each other, because the families stuck together, like my mother’s family was quite a large family, and my father’s family was quite a large family. I mean, they were not so large, like there were six, and in my mother’s family there were six. And they all had children there — not married, they were still all young before the war.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: I mean, married age came during the war.

segments.question: That’s right.
segments.answer: But before the war they were still all like 16 - 15 - 14 years old. So mostly — especially you — you knew very much your neighbors, because we were like close knit and living very close to each other. So —

segments.question: Which parent were you closer to?
segments.answer: Which grandparents?

segments.question: Parent. Parent. Your mother or your father, who did you feel closer to?
segments.answer: I think there were times when I was very close with my mother as a child. My father didn’t have time for anything, cause he was always, always working —

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: — in order to provide for the family. And then — well, this was before the war.

segments.question: Yeah. Contact reference@ushmm org for further information about this collection Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas " May 5, 2013
segments.answer: It changed differently later on.

segments.question: Uh-huh, okay. I-Is that it changed during the war?
segments.answer: I-It — it changed — in 1938 my father was drafted to the Polish army.

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: And everybody was very stunned because already he — that time he was in the 40s, and he was like the only Jew who was drafted to the Polish army, and nobody could understand why. So of course it was very hard for my mother with the three of us to make a living, or support us. We went to my grandfather, to my father’s father. He had a big house, he had room for us, and he told us to come there. So we lived together until the war.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: And we didn’t hear from my father if he’s alive or not, where he is. He was fighting. When the war started, he had to fight with the Polish army, the Germans.

segments.question: That was — must have been very frightening.
segments.answer: It was very frightening and when they start to bomb the city, we all escaped like to a village, not far from Rozwadow, and then we came back. And we never went home again. And my mother stayed with us, with my grandfather, my grandmother had died just before, a few years. We stayed, and also my aunt and uncle. And their Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas : May 5, 2013 children all stayed at the same house until the Germans march into Poland, to our city.

segments.question: I want to stop there. I still want to talk a little bit about pre-war.
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: Do you have an earliest memory”?
segments.answer: Excuse me?

segments.question: Do you have an earliest memory? Do you have, you know, as a child growing up, one of your — the earliest things that — that you can remember’?
segments.answer: I could — I could remember that anti-Semitism started. I felt — not only I, the whole family, that short before the war, the antemitism(ph) got much more —

segments.question: Strong?
segments.answer: — intensive, you know, and it was scary to go out, especially at night, especially before a Christmas holiday, my father never let us out in the street, because the Polish people, they are very, very susceptible to drinking. And whoever they saw they could have beat up or something, and it was scary to go out. So this I remember very well when I got older a little bit, not when I was very young. When I was very young, I was like very free to roam around, not the city, but near the house. We had the little park, you know, we had swings. So it wasn’t like I had to Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas me May 5, 2013 go far away that’s my mother couldn’t call me in when she felt it’s time to get into the house. So —

segments.question: So-
segments.answer: — I was —I was a happy child.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: And had very good friends.

segments.answer: Yeah, I had friends, we — we were very happy, you know. I remember I had a friend, she was rich, and they had the telephone in the house, and also a doll —a doll and a carriage. We all got together and play with her dolls and with the carriage. It was like, even for a person who didn’t make a living for the family, but you couldn’t afforded those things. So if somebody was able to afford it, well, they had the beer factory, that friend of mine. She didn’t survive the war.

segments.question: What was her name?
segments.answer: Excuse me?

segments.question: What was her name?
segments.answer: The name was Sandrovich(ph). Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas " May 5, 2013

segments.answer: I don’t remember.

segments.answer: Bronya(ph) Bronya(ph).

segments.question: Bronya(ph) Bronya(ph).
segments.answer: Bronya(ph) Sandrovich(ph), yeah.

segments.answer: It’s coming back.

segments.question: It does, it does.
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: So-
segments.answer: So we used to play in their backyard with the carriage, with the doll. And then one time it came to my home, we went home. But we looked forward the next time again to meet. But I had three friends. One you met on my picture.

segments.question: What’s her name?
segments.answer: Sonya Olst(ph).

segments.question: Okay. Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas " May 5, 2013
segments.answer: She — she’s now — she’s very, very, very sick. She has cancer all over, she’s a doctor herself, but she’s very, very sick, hardly surviving, I don’t know how much longer she will survive. I speak to her once in a while. And we were close, we went always together, skating, to school, to — to public school, to Hebrew school. We were like three of us always, always together, never separating. And on Shabbas we used to go for — they had for the kids, they had like little lectures, you know, singing. And this was also gathering everything on religious basis, nothing out of the ordinary, which didn’t belong to us. But there were also kids who were like in different organizations. And we always belonged to the Mizrachi.

segments.question: Mizrachi.
segments.answer: And the Mizrachi is a working religious organization, and mine brothers were also — my father made sure that’s my brothers that every Shabbas go to the meetings, and so some learning for the Polon(ph) Mizrachi, which is working religious people. Course my father belonged to that organization.

segments.question: So that meant for —
segments.answer: So as children, we were raised like — with love to Israel, and that time Palestine, but that no — we knew that eventually, maybe, one day we’ll go to Israel, that time Palestine. segments.question: And so that sense, that — that mission, was something that was very conscious for you, aS you were growing up, that Israel is a pla — 1s the homeland.
segments.answer: Palestine.

segments.question: That Palestine is the homeland.
segments.answer: Yeah, my father was a Zionist. He always attended his meetings, and he always intend that’s one day he’s gonna be in Israel. But he never made it.

segments.question: Yeah. You — who were — what was the name of your other friend, you had three of you.
segments.answer: Yeah, the Olst(ph) family, they also were — when the Germans came in, we were living with them for a couple of weeks. And one day they announced that we should get a — then the bomb stops, because they had already occupied them.

segments.question: Okay, excuse me, I don’t want to get to the war yet.
segments.answer: Okay.

segments.question: We’ll get to the war. I wanted to know the name of the other girl. You were three of you who were all —
segments.answer: Shifka(ph) rose — Shifka(ph) Wiesenfeld(ph).

segments.question: Shifka(ph) Wiesenfeld(ph).
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: And do you know what happened to her? Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas May 5, 2013
segments.answer: Yes, they perished by the Germans.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: The whole family.

segments.question: So it was the three of you —
segments.answer: Separated, yeah.

segments.question: — sep — yeah, who event — yeah, were separated, but as children, you were the closest friends.
segments.answer: Yes, we were separated as children when the war — when the Germans came into the town.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: And they occupied.

segments.question: I have one more question before we come to that.
segments.answer: Mm-hm?

segments.question: And that is about your relations with local Polish people. I know you mentioned that anti-Semitism got very strong right before the war, but —
segments.answer: Yeah, only good relation we had is with the — our teacher.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: Polish lady. She was very nice to — to all the kids, and that’s the only Polish person that I really knew at home. We didn’t associate with any Polacks at all. Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas " May 5, 2013

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: Even in school, we had our own — our own Jewish kids which we play together during the recesses and mostly we kept to ourselves.

segments.question: Okay. So now let’s come to the war.
segments.answer: Okay.

segments.question: How much talk was there in your home about Hitler, about what was going on in Germany?
segments.answer: Nothing. Nothing.

segments.question: Nothing?
segments.answer: Nothing. It was like — it was like a bomb, you know, like an — where they were bombing us first, like I said, we had — my mother took us, we escaped to a village, maybe there would be less bombing. But they were so low in the planes, that’s — I remember like vividly I seeing them now. They could have killed everybody, but somehow —

segments.question: Were you on the road?
segments.answer: We were on the road.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Trying to escape the city. But then when the bombing stopped, we came back.

segments.question: Okay. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas May 5, 2013
segments.answer: Not to our house, like I said, to my grandfather’s house, and we stayed there until the Germans moved in. Nobody talked about Hitler, nobody talked about the Germans. We only heard — nobody had the radio in those years — we heard that France was occupied, Belgium was occupied, all these countries, and Poland was like the next on the road. They came in, it was just before the Jewish holidays, and they settled themselves to the best houses, which they occupy half of my zayde’s house, my grandfather’s. Course, he had like a double house. And they were very — those were young, very young Austrian soldiers. They were quiet, pleasant. They said don’t worry, we’re not going to do nothing to you. That’s how I remember tt. And it was settled, you know, everything is going to be okay. Few weeks later when they took my older brother to work, he was that time already 14 years old.

segments.question: Pinchus(ph).
segments.answer: Outside the town, I don’t know what to do, I have no idea. Oh, maybe I had an idea, but I don’t remember. Then he came home at night a few days later, we heard the loudspeakers in the market, you know, it the city hall, that all the Jewish people should gather at this and this time in the marketplace, and there will be an announcement made. So the announcement was that every Jew has to leave Rozwadow immediately. You could go home, take whatever you can, and leave the town. Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas oS May 5, 2013

segments.question: What a shock.
segments.answer: It was — for my mother it wasn’t a shock, because she wanted to go and find my father. She didn’t know where he 1s, she never — we never heard from him. She had a feeling that he is someplace alive. So she gathered us, we put on like — I remember like — I put on like three dresses, or whatever and two coats, and hats. It was already September, October, something like this. And my brothers, whatever they had in a little bundle on the back. And my zayde went, my grandfather, my father’s father. My cante(ph) with her three kids and her husband. We went to the San. The San is the river which divided our city in half.

segments.question: Ah, so Rozwadow was on the San river.
segments.answer: Rozwadow was on the San, yeah.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: And that’s what — the city where my husband comes, also on the San, but they were on the Ukrainian side, we were on the Galician side, on the Polish side. So —

segments.question: Were the cities far from each other?
segments.answer: Yes, yes.

segments.question: [indecipherable] far?
segments.answer: Yes, because they were like, near the Ukraine.

segments.question: I see. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas a“ May 5, 2013
segments.answer: And we were near — and we were in middle of Poland, that called Irlitsia(ph) in that time.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: It still — it still is called Irlitsia(ph).

segments.question: Irlitsia(ph)
segments.answer: — I think, I — I’m not sure. So everybody who was able to work, the kids, the old people, the young people, and some people didn’t leave. Some people were hiding in their homes. We left. We got on the San, hurry across the San. The bridge was already bombard to pieces. So, of course if you have a little money, my grandfather got a Polish guy who had a little, like a fishing boat or something. So the family got into that boat, and many people drowned, because they were walking in the water. They didn’t think it’s that deep, but it was deep. Many, many people drowned. And we got to the other side. On the other side we had a small village, but it was prosperous village, where my father’s brother lived, his wife and his father-in-law and his child.

segments.question: Wait, what was the name of the village?
segments.answer: [indecipherable] I'll tell you in a minute. Justkowicz(ph).

segments.question: Justkowicz(ph).
segments.answer: Justkowicz(ph), yeah. Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas _ May 5, 2013

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: So we stayed in their house —

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: — because we were family, for a few days. And my mother saw Polish soldiers coming home from the war, every — and she knew a lot of the — a lot of the old customers of my father. So she used to ask them if they ever saw my u — my father. They said yes, he’s alive, but he’s in the German side, in Premisz(ph).

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Premisz(ph) was also, one side was the Russian, and one side also was the zerc — I mean, the water in the middle — one side was the Russians occupied, one side was the Germans. My father fell in into the German side, as a Polish soldier.

segments.question: When — can — before I go there, just to establish, when you were in the village with your father’s brother, was that occupied by the Russians at that point?
segments.answer: Not my father’s brother — yeah, my father’s brother —

segments.question: [indecipherable] father’s brother.
segments.answer: — Benny.

segments.question: Yeah. Was that —
segments.answer: Yeah. It was occupied — was an 0 — was occupied by nobody.

segments.question: I see. Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas “° May 5, 2013
segments.answer: The Russians were starting to come in.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: They were starting to come in, but they didn’t get that fast to that area.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: The Germans got much faster to the other side where we lived. So my mother said no, she’s gonna take her children, and she’s gonna go and walk to meet the Russians. And we were constant, constant, we saw Polish — Polish soldiers coming back from the army, which were already, you know, army that time was already —

segments.question: What did they look like, these soldiers, as they were coming back?
segments.answer: Tired, exhausted. And they were glad that they still were alive and coming home.

segments.question: Did they say anything of what happened?
segments.answer: N-No, didn’t say nothing. We stayed in Pishnison(ph), which was the je — which were the border of the Germans, and the border of the Russians.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: This was a cousin of my uncle.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: She let us stay there in one room, all of us, my aunt with the three kids, an uncle, my grandfather and my — and us, my mother and three kids. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas ot May 5, 2013

segments.question: Oh my gosh.
segments.answer: Yeah. One very dark room, but at least, after walking for miles and miles and miles with the bundle and all dressed up, we finally got to Pishnison(ph), and we stayed there. The Russians were already occupied that town. We stayed there for awhile, maybe a week or something, til we got our strength back. My mother picked herself up, she left us with my aunt and uncle, and she took the [indecipherable] to Lwow, because she had a feeling that maybe she’ll find my father.

segments.question: Was Lwow under the Germans at that point?
segments.answer: No, Lwow was under the Russians.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Under the Russians.

segments.question: Even though she had been told he was in a prison in a town —
segments.answer: Yeah, but we don’t know what happened after.

segments.question: That’s right.
segments.answer: After the war, or —

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: — how he got out or —

segments.question: Right. Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas “ May 5, 2013
segments.answer: — where he was. So she went to Lwoéw, she was never in Lwow. I don’t know how she had the courage to go there, and she was walking around the whole city, asking people if they ever saw my father, if they know where he 1s, and if this — if he survived. Somehow, my father survived. He was kept in a camp, in a German camp for a while, and I don’t know how he escaped, and he crossed the border to Lwow.

segments.question: So even though she didn’t know, and he didn’t know, they ended up in the same city.
segments.answer: In the same city, and somehow all the refugees at tho — at that time they all stuck together, they — everybody was trying to find somebody they know.

segments.question: Sounds like huge chaos.
segments.answer: In Lwow, yes, little — in 1939, yes, 1940. And she found him. And she came back, she said to my — to his father, my zayde and — and to his sister, she said, I’m taking my kids, I’m going to Lwow, I found my husband. So we were so happy, and took the train, we went to Lwéw and they gave us the — like a committee, a Jewish committee. There still was a lot of — lot of Jews before the war there. They arranged something for us to sleep in a Polish cathedral, you know, we slept —

segments.question: Was it the first time you were in a Polish church — in a Catholic church? Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas ” May 5, 2013
segments.answer: Yeah, yeah, in a Catholic church. I remember even the street was Matskavich(ph), the street was Matskavich(ph), I can — how I remember this, I don’t know.

segments.question: Do you have a —
segments.answer: It was — it was not a church, it was like a cathedral you know, like —

segments.question: So it’s a huge place.
segments.answer: Very huge. So the — and the Polacks there, and the priests gave us the downstairs. Not only us, where — there was a lot of refugees. We slept there on the floor for a good while. But at least we were together.

segments.question: Did you have any food? Did anybody give you any food?
segments.answer: I don’t remember that.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: We probably got food from the people — from the Jewish people who lived before the war in Lwow.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: We got some food from them probably, I don’t — I — I don’t remember.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: I remem — and then my — we were still there. Of cour — of course, afraid from the Polacks. But we weren’t alone, we were a lot of us there. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas * May 5, 2013

segments.question: But were there also Polish refugees in that basement?
segments.answer: No, no, no, no.

segments.question: Just Jewish?
segments.answer: Just Jews, no.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: The Polish people didn’t have to leave the city or go by themselves or anything. My parents went to look for a place where they could live with Jews together and not in a cathedral. So they found not far from the marketplace, a big house, which perl — probably belonged to Jews, and they gave out floors for those people.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: Now it was empty, we slept on the floors. So there was I don’t know how many families. We had a little space, all five slept together and had the little [indecipherable] or whatever they gave us to cook something. And we lived there and I started Russian schools.

segments.question: You started to go to school in r — had you s — ah, one question I had, did you see Russian soldiers in Lwow?
segments.answer: Of course.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: In Lwow. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas * May 5, 2013

segments.question: When was the first time you saw Russian soldiers, and I’d like to know —
segments.answer: In Lwow.

segments.question: In Lwow.
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: Did you have it in — what impression did they make on you?
segments.answer: I wasn’t scared.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: I was too young, I thou — I thought it’s funny.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: You know.

segments.question: They look different, huh?
segments.answer: I—I saw —I saw the German soldiers. They were much cleaner looking than the Russian soldiers. Different outfits, different everything. But they didn’t bother us, they let us roam around free. If you can buy something on the black market, if you had some money for food or something, you bought whatever you could. And that’s how we survived for 1940 — 1939 - 1940. And I started Russian school. I was that time going in the — in the fifth grade, maybe sixth grade.

segments.question: So how old were you?
segments.answer: I was that time by 11. Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas * May 5, 2013

segments.question: So you — as a— you were a young child when this 1s all happening to you.
segments.answer: When the war broke out, I was nine years old.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: That’s why I couldn’t understand all this politics. I remember now —

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: — what will happen that — that time.

segments.question: But it’s import —
segments.answer: But didn’t — I — those years I didn’t realize. I was only nine years old. What do I know about the war?

segments.question: Of course, of course.
segments.answer: What do I think about the war.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: So after my father decided in 1940, a lot of people decided that’s they going. There was a committee to register who wants to go back to Poland, to the — to home.

segments.question: Af—I want to ask a question, though.
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: When you started school and you — 1-it was Russian school, so you’re starting to learn Russian, yes? Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas “ May 5, 2013
segments.answer: Russian and Jewish.

segments.question: Russian and Jew — so you were able to study in Yiddish, or in —
segments.answer: In Yiddish and Russian, yeah, they were Jewish teachers.

segments.question: And it was a public school? Or was a religious school?
segments.answer: It was a — supposedly — no, no, a public.

segments.question: A public school.
segments.answer: Public school. And just wanted the children to do something with themselves, otherwise they would get crazy.

segments.question: Of course.
segments.answer: They were —

segments.question: And do you have any impressions of this school?
segments.answer: Excuse me?

segments.question: Do you have any memories of the school?
segments.answer: Not much.

segments.question: What would you remember from it?
segments.answer: I remember to learn Russian that time. You know, beginning. They didn’t last long, maybe a few months. After my father went to register that’s he want to go back to Poland, not only him, they were standing in the line for days. And then he came home happy that’s — who knew the war 1s going to be for six years, nobody Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas ~ May 5, 2013 knew. That’s eventually they will let us go back to Poland, you know, to the home. So instead of keeping the promise that they’re gonna let us go home, the Russians took over. All the people who registered to go home, they got them together from all over, no matter where you were, and that was on a Friday night, I remember like now. My mother had cooked something for Shabbas. The Russians came 1n, because they knew where all the refugees were living, the Russians came in and they said, get yourself together immediately. We didn’t know what happened, we were sleeping. My parents woke us up, we got dressed. Then my mother took whatever she cooked, you know, for Shabbas, and they took us to the trains. Not knowing where we going, not knowing nothing. Hungry and naked and everybody get up like they know how to do it, very rough.

data: So the manner was different from what you had ac — been experiencing up til then’? The way the soldiers behaved was different than what you had experienced in Lwow until that time.

Well, this was — this was like a — they — they had a — they were told they have to do that, but first, in one night they got together, the whole refugee or whoever — wherever they were, if they knew who they were. And when we came those trains, we met already my aunt, with her kids, and my uncle, and my grandfather and a lot of other families from other people my parents knew. And they put us in cattle Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas * May 5, 2013 trains, hundreds of people in one train. You only have standing place. We stood like — worse than cattles. And then the Ukrainian, the goyim, they were the happiest in the world. They were clapping and they were dancing, and they were whatnot.

segments.question: You saw that?
segments.answer: Yes, we saw that before we even went to the trains. So they — they knew they’ Il have plenty of what to — you know, take away whate — whatever the Jews left. But they didn’t take the people who did not register. They only took the people who registered they want go back. Which means you wanted to go back to — to Germany, to be in that — on the Hitler side, but Hitler wasn’t, you know, on the other side of Poland.

segments.question: But here’s a question. If — knowing that, knowing that — that it’s on the German side, why did your father want to go home?
segments.answer: They didn’t think it’s gonna take — the war was — God knows they — they thought after the pact, you know, when the — Hitler did the pact with Russia, it’s gonna be one, two, three and they’re gonna divide, and you can go home and be yourself like you were before. That’s what you thought.

segments.question: So they knew about the pact. They knew —
segments.answer: Oh yeah, we knew about the pact, you know. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas *° May 5, 2013

segments.question: You knew the pact.
segments.answer: There never gonna be a war with Russia and Germany. They’re gonna divide whatever they took, and that’s how it’s gonna be finished. So who didn’t want to go home to their places where they were born, raised and — and worked and everything’? So — and they took us to the cattle trains, and then they were filled up with different families, we didn’t know who they were. We didn’t know none of them.

segments.question: Were any refugees not Jewish? Are you saying all of the refugees were Jewish?
segments.answer: All Jewish.

segments.question: All Jewish.
segments.answer: All Jewish, only Jews.

segments.question: Only Jews, okay.
segments.answer: So — and we traveled, we traveled for a whole month. They stopped in certain places, which they let us go out in case you had to go out. Otherwise there was nothing inside that you could relieve yourself. That was crying and crying and getting sick and it was — I'll never forget that. We were only kids. My oldest brother was 15, my middle brother was 13 and I was 10.

segments.question: You didn’t know where you were going?
segments.answer: No. Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas 7 May 5, 2013

segments.question: You knew it wasn’t home, however.
segments.answer: No, no, we knew right away, yeah, we knew it. Because it didn’t go the side like to Poland, it was now the way we going my — they used to stop like maybe after few weeks of traveling, or a week, so that people came to the — to the trains, and they gave us like [indecipherable] like hot water to bring something. There was no food, there was nothing.

segments.question: So you got no food in the trains, nobody fed you.
segments.answer: Nothing.

segments.question: Well, how could someone survive no water and no food?
segments.answer: Nothing, nothing, just -— we remember stopping, and this was already Russia. We — we didn’t know where we were. They came to the trains with buckets of hot water and it was like a Godsend, you know. Food? There was nothing. They didn’t feed us at all, from —

segments.question: What time of year was it?
segments.answer: Excuse me?

segments.question: What time of year was it?
segments.answer: This was end of ’40 — of — end of °40.

segments.question: So it was December? Sort of like November, December? Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas . May 5, 2013
segments.answer: No, we — when we came to the Urals, it was already winter, because they took us off the train with sleds, and they brought us to — 1n the Urals, which was camps and barracks, and — and the steppes, you know, steppes? I don’t know if you know what the steppes are in Russia.

segments.question: Tell me, what does it — what does it look like, a steppe?
segments.answer: It’s fields, empty, empty fields, around, around on the Ural mountains. It’s like on the border with Europe and — and Europe and Asia, divided. This was the ur — the —

segments.question: Okay. So a steppe is an open field?
segments.answer: Yeah, that’s what the steppes are, it’s very open, you know, a lot of empty like fields. Not growing anything, nothing.

segments.question: So it’s like just — just empty.
segments.answer: Steppe — yeah, empty.

segments.question: No trees.
segments.answer: No, no. No trees. Then when — when they brought us to the barracks, to the little place which was called [speaks foreign language] I don’t remember exactly, and there were barracks, which they had kept — many years ago they kept over there like prisoners of war or something, I don’t know. And they divided everybody to a barrack room. Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas ” May 5, 2013

segments.question: Was your family kept together?
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: We - our family, and another family, we were — we were given one room. One r — the room was maybe half as high as what this. So we slept on one side, and the other family of four slept on this side, in the barracks.

segments.question: Tell me, what kind of conversation — do you remember what people were saying to one another in the trains, as they were being taken into Russia?
segments.answer: I don’t remember.

segments.question: Were the people praying? Do you remember if they were praying?
segments.answer: Everybody was praying. It didn’t help, but they were praying.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: Praying to God, not knowing where we were going to be, or what’s going to happen.

segments.question: Did your — was there much — did the guards, or did anybody official in a uniform or anything like that —
segments.answer: No, the guards were outside the train.

segments.question: They were just guarding that you don’t leave it? Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas " May 5, 2013
segments.answer: Yeah. No, we were locked like, you know, with the bolt. And when they stopped — when the people, like some of the people brought us hot water —

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: — they opened up the bolt and they shoulder — they opened the doors so everybody could get some water to drink.

segments.question: I see. And did they say anything to you when you were brought to those barracks? So you didn’t know why you were there.
segments.answer: They — no. We — we assumed, because mostly people had registered to go back, and that’s why they were there, probably.

segments.question: Okay, but no speeches, no explanation?
segments.answer: Nothing, nothing. We came — the one of the cities, I think 1t was Molotov that time, which is like a main city in the Urals. I’m reading now a book about it also, from dur-during the war, and when I saw Molotov I rem — or Kora Stalowka(ph), this was a place where we were, the — the little enclave like a few barracks and on one side were the woods, with lions or with tigers and whatever. Or hyenas, you know it’s scary to death. But somehow, we lived through. So [indecipherable] barracks like this, you know, and — like barracks, you know what barracks a-are.

segments.question: So the barracks, were they inside the woods, or on the steppe?
segments.answer: On the steppe where it was a clearing. Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas " May 5, 2013

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: But the mountains and the woods were all around.

segments.question: Got it.
segments.answer: And this was like a clearing.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: But we had the commando there, Russian commando. After they settled everybody in the house over there where we lived, they started to choose people for work. Of course, the work was in the woods, to cut woods.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: You know. They took my mother, they took my older brother and my father was not well since he got out from the army, he went to a committee and they said he cannot work. And they let me and my younger brother — my middle brother, also didn’t take because we were too young. They took from like 16 and up. So they took my mother and my brother. And that’s where they worked all winter, sawing trees and putting them into the water for transportation. And it was 60 below zero.

segments.question: And what kind of clothes did they have?
segments.answer: Codes?

segments.question: Clothes, what kind of clothes did they have? Contact reference@ushmm org for further information about this collection Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas * May 5, 2013
segments.answer: Whatever we brought from home, whatever we had. Everything was cold and torn, no-nothing special. Freezing to death. We survived, I don’t know. I don’t know how we survived.

segments.question: Do you remember the food? If — what kind of food you had?
segments.answer: The food?

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: Yeah, they gave us like maybe 200 gram of bread, like stone was the bread. Maybe the workers got a little bit more. And there was a kitchen, soup kitchen, so everybody had to go with a little thing to get some soup. This was our food.

segments.question: Were you hungry?
segments.answer: Always. But my — in the summer my mother discovered chives. You know chives, the green, between the grass? She recognized which ones are looking like chives, so she collected that when she was able to. And she also collected — there is a green grass which is very itchy, I don’t know how it’s called.

segments.question: I don’t know.
segments.answer: It — it — it looks like spinach, it grows like spinach, but the leaves are very sharp and itchy.

segments.question: Would it be nettles?
segments.answer: I don’t know how it’s called in English. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas “ May 5, 2013

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: If you go touch it here, you would —

segments.question: Do you know what it’s called in Russian?
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: Or in Polish? Or in Yiddish?
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: No. You don’t know what it’s called, okay.
segments.answer: Yeah, pokrzywy.

segments.question: Pokrzywy.
segments.answer: In Polish it’s called pokrzywy. In Jewish, I don’t have no idea. So she collected that, and from this she cooked soup. And this was our vitamin. And it was pretty good. Just water, washed it, whatever she could. The chives, the pokrzywy, little salt, water and this was the additional soup what we got from the soup kitchen.

segments.question: So it was bread that was hard, and this. And that’s what you got to —
segments.answer: That’s [indecipherable]. Then the summer came, my brothers were very good blueberry pickers. They went to the woods and they came home with buckets of blueberries. Not blueberries like here, cultivated, really blueberries, growing on the ground. And they used to sell 1t to people who couldn’t go collect this. So we got a few rubles, whatever that time it was, and then my mother collected a few things Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas “ May 5, 2013 with myself, like we had a—a nice tablecloth, we had some socks what we brought from home. And we went to a village far away and brought home some potatoes, some eggs. Not much, but we — whatever we had, we [indecipherable]

segments.question: So you were —
segments.answer: And that’s how we lived through the summer.

segments.question: So you were allowed to leave the barracks. It wasn’t like you were imprisoned within —
segments.answer: Hel — the barracks were surrounded, you cannot get out, like out to go. You had to have [indecipherable] document if you want to go to the next village. It was the same thing. But there were Gentiles living, Russians there, many, many years. And they had their little farm, you know, and they had like what to eat.

segments.question: Mm-hm. But they were — the — the commandants of this commando and so on, it wasn’t that you were in a prison where they wouldn’t let you out at all. You ne —
segments.answer: Oh we — we could — we could walk around in the barracks whatever — I mean, outside.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: They had to go to work and some — they weren’t like going [indecipherable] you know, with the rifle, but they were going to work every single day, Shabbas and Sunday, was no question about it. Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas . May 5, 2013

segments.question: Did you go — did you were insi — were — because you and your younger brother and your father didn’t go, what did you do with yourselves during the day?
segments.answer: I — to tell you the truth, there was no schools, we — the children used to play, you know, get together and play whatever, running around in the summer, not in the winter.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: And not much, you know, it was a very boring life, scary, hungry, no food, no nothing.

segments.question: What were you scared of the most?
segments.answer: I’m gonna die there, because many people died from hunger. And there were people who were — mostly intelligentsia, which they weren’t used to that type of life, they didn’t know how to help themselves, and a lot of them, a lot of them, a lot of them died, just like in the concentration camps, from hunger. You live on — on 200 gram of bread, which was hard like the earth, I don’t know, they probably baked it with — with earth or something, I don’t know. Supposedly this was bread [indecipherable] my mother went to another village to be able to collect something like a potato, like whatever, you know, an egg, a potato, a carrot. So she divided it for everybody. And my father was getting more sick and sick and sick and no Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas “° May 5, 2013 hospitals. The only thing — and the doctor always gave him the paper that he cannot work.

segments.question: So the doctor didn’t treat him, but he gave him a paper he can’t work.
segments.answer: That he can’t work, he couldn’t work. He couldn’t work —

segments.question: Was he changed, was he —
segments.answer: — he couldn’t work, he was a — he was on — knocked out from the prison in Germany [indecipherable] he was very weak.

segments.question: Tell me, earlier, when I asked you which parent you were closer to, and you said, as growing up, it was my mother, but that changed. How did that change and when did that change?
segments.answer: It changed because my father was sick. Got very close to him.

segments.question: Did you talk?
segments.answer: And — and my mother was always upset, because she had to work, and she couldn’t supply enough for everybody. So it was like — and my father couldn’t help her, so we were like divided, you know.

segments.question: Were they — were they angry with each other?
segments.answer: No, no, my father was very good man. Sometimes he was strict, you know, and we listened to him. But my mother was the supplier of everything.

segments.question: He was quite a burden on her. Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas a May 5, 2013
segments.answer: Yeah. To feed us, to find a grass she could cook. She worked hard to get a little bit more bread, something. It wasn’t easy. This was going on until Yom Kippur. Yom Kippur my mother and my brother didn’t go to work. They went to — there was a Jewish cemetery where my father was — where my grandfather was buried. I don’t know, probably — oh no, this was already later, I’m sorry.

segments.question: Okay. It was —
segments.answer: No. No, no, no, it was still in the camps. They didn’t go to work, to the woods, you know, to — it was Yom Kippur. So 16 Jewish men and women, I remember exactly the amount ...

segments.question: It’s okay.
segments.answer: — were taken to the city of Molotov to be prosecuted, because they didn’t work on Yom Kippur. And we went — we didn’t know if we were going to see them again or not.

segments.question: So, included your mother?
segments.answer: Yes. Not my brother, my mother and 16 other people, men — men and women. But it took a few days, we didn’t know what’s gonna be, because they only let those people go under, you know, with soldiers, on the watch of the Soviet commando, whatever they were. And they were freed. It was like the biggest thing what ever happened, that time. They let them all go. They — and the judge, I don’t Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas . May 5, 2013 know if it was Jewish, it was a Russian Jew or some, I don’t know, he listened to their story and they said they had never worked on Yom Kippur, and even if they died, they would never work on Yom Kippur. And they let them free, everybody came home. I mean, home to them. [indecipherable]

segments.question: Yeah. But it must have been everyone was terrified.
segments.answer: Oh yeah, [indecipherable] when they took them, we were all terrif — we never knew if they’re gonna come back or if they were going to put them to jail.

segments.question: Had you — you said earlier that a lot of people were dying from hunger.
segments.answer: Yes, a lot.

segments.question: Were there — did you see any people dying from brutality, that is, of the guards to these people?
segments.answer: No, no, no.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: No. No, only from hunger.

segments.question: Only from hunger.
segments.answer: The one beaten — I don’t know if they were beaten when they were working —

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: — because they were working under the eye — under the open eye of the soldiers, but I don’t know because I was — my mother never said it. Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas ” May 5, 2013

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: But not that’s in the barracks they were beaten, but people just died from hunger.

segments.question: Okay. Did your mother talk about what — what it was like there to be in that jail before that judge?
segments.answer: No, no, mm-mm, no, no. My mother and brother also didn’t talk about it.

segments.question: When —
segments.answer: Just — they just went to work at six o’clock in the morning, they came home before dark, or dark in the winter and they never — just be glad to be home and go to that magazine, whatever they had, get their payok(ph) they called it, you know, the grams of bread, whatever, and the soup. And they came home and this was it, there was nothing specific. I know I remember I was learning how to play cards, you know the regular, you know.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: And there was a gentleman, he was a doctor from Krakow, me and him got very, you know, he was a very nice young man. He taught me how to — how to play cards, so we — and he also didn’t work. So we played cards all day, you know. And now I don’t know how to play cards at all. I didn’t proceed with it, so this was my entertainment. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas ” May 5, 2013

segments.question: What about your father? How were things going with him?
segments.answer: And after June 22", 1941, when the war broke out with Russia and Germany, all the Polish people who were in camps, were liberated. Liberated to go to any place in Russia you choose.

segments.question: How did you hear about it?
segments.answer: Excuse me?

segments.question: How did — how did that news come to you?
segments.answer: I don’t —

segments.question: I mean — so that’s — that’s the event that happened. Was it that somebody came and announced it in your barracks? Would — did the soldiers come?
segments.answer: Yes, yes, they announced it, they announced it, that’s all the prisoners in the camps are liberated because the war started to Germany, which they thought, and they hoped that a lot of the people who were in the barracks and the prison will join the Russian army to fight the Germans. Which a lot of did. Which my uncle did, my cousin did, and they both — they both died in the Warsaw from the fighting, both of them, father and son. A lot of people joined the army, and they went to fight the Germans, because in Ural was very quiet, we didn’t feel the war.

segments.question: Yeah, yeah.
segments.answer: In 1942, the Polish — they organized the Polish army in Russia. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas May 5, 2013

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: From Polish Jews and Polacks, wherever they were, and they also joined the Russian army. So is —

segments.question: Did anybody from your family do that?
segments.answer: No, they were too young.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: And my father was sick. But then we started to get food, just the Polish people who have lived in Poland, we started to get food from America through the Polish army.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: That time, was a lady by the name of Anda(ph) Vashalewska(ph) who organized this Polish army with the English.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: And they were fighting from [indecipherable] they went to the front, the Russian front. A lot of j — a lot of Jewish boys joined the Polish army, and they started to feed the Polish people much better. We used to get also like a pay — like an amount in — in the boxes, milk, some tuna fish, some flour, some sugar. 1943 we started to be able to eat a little bit better. So people came to themselves much stronger. This was al — this was already when we left the Urals. On the way Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas ~ May 5, 2013 already, being freed from the camps, the family who lived with us, their name was also Buch, but we no — were no family, the parents died in the sled, both of them, the husband and the wife. The two girls were left alone. They — they are a — still alive in Israel, I know they were in Israel. Had to come back and bury them, and then we were freed. I don’t know, somehow my father got in touch with his sister.

segments.question: Where was his sister living?
segments.answer: His sister, the one we were together in — 1n the [indecipherable] you know, in the Russian occupied territory. And we, through letters, or through people, I-I don’t remember all the details, that’s we’re gonna go towards [indecipherable] by Troitsk.

segments.question: Troitsk.
segments.answer: Which was near Chelyabinsk.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: And not far from Molotov.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: So we — we settled in — not many settled there. A lot of people went to the warm countries, the [indecipherable] to Kazakhstan, to all these republics, you know. But my father said he doesn’t have the strength to travel that far, he’s going to go to the nearest town which 1s free. I mean, we were free. segments.question: So tell me —
segments.answer: We could do whatever we wanted. And this was from 19 — end of 1942 til the end of the war in 1945. I went — I went to a normal school —

segments.question: Hang on. I’ll ask you questions, but I want to —
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: — go back a little bit. Those two girls, what happened to them after their parents — you buried their parents?
segments.answer: They — I don’t know where they went. I have no idea.

segments.question: Were they teenagers, were they young ladies?
segments.answer: Teenagers, yes, teenagers.

segments.question: So they weren’t children?
segments.answer: No, no, they were not — they were teenagers like 18 maybe, 19 —17.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: They were teenagers, yes.

segments.question: How had it been, living with that family in that one room, in that barracks?
segments.answer: You know, you sleep like this.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: And you can’t turn. If you turn, the whole group had to turn. It’s like you go to sleep on the floor, and you are close to each other, and that’s how you slept. Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas ~ May 5, 2013

segments.question: Very difficult, no privacy.
segments.answer: Privacy, forget about privacy. And if you had to go out, you had to go out on the outhouse. It wasn’t like a house, it was like a hole in the ground. And you were afraid, because there were the monsters, some animal shouldn’t come out and — you know. But we lived through, I ge — I guess God gave us years to live, so we lived through.

segments.question: But you were the youngest.
segments.answer: An-And — so after we were freed, we got — which was very hard, it was, again, everything was rationed. We got even a little bit more than the Russian people. But the Russian people had their cows, their — their whatever, chickens. But we didn’t have anything, so we lived whatever we were able to buy on the black market. My father got a job.

segments.question: In Chelyabinsk?
segments.answer: In Troitsk.

segments.question: In Troitsk, excuse me.
segments.answer: In Troitsk, yeah. Chelyabinsk was the main city.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: He got a job in a factory making, like I said, the top of the shoes.

segments.question: Same thing as before. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas * May 5, 2013
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: Uppers.
segments.answer: Upper, only the upper. My brother got a job — my older brother, together with my father in the same place.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: So they got a little bit, you know, paid. I started school.

segments.question: Did you know Russian by this point?
segments.answer: Yes, yes, I did. Not maybe perfect, but I had the beginning in Lwoéw, and of course in the — in the camps, they spoke only Russian, you know, in — when we were incarcenated in the camps. So, I started school, and until the end of the war I was in school. My younger brother learned how to — my middle brother learned how to make the — not letter, but from some type of material, like the Chinese are wearing, you know, those very — it looks like — it looks like a house shoe you know, like a — I don’t know how it’s called.

segments.question: Slippers of some kind?
