But thank God they never got into the store. I was shivering like crazy, I was afraid, and the guy was afraid too, because he was hiding me. Well, thank God evening came. Somehow I got out, I went home and I never went to sell them again, never.

segments.question: Did you tell your mother what had happened?
segments.answer: Oh yeah, they knew what happened, my mother knew. My mother was there when I started to run, so she hide everything under her, whatever she had, and I never went out to sell them again, never. I continued —

segments.question: What kind of — yeah, what kind of — what kind of information did you have about the NK VD? Why were they so scary? Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas May 5, 2013
segments.answer: Why they were so scary? When my brother worked in a factory, you know, my older brother, from coconut. This was before he got this job where my father worked. So he used to bring home once in a while the carket(ph), the shell, from the coconut, the shell. It was like sugar and milk and everything else. Before he left the factory, he threw out some through the gate. And then he went to collect it, and they caught him, and they took him to jail. We didn’t know why he didn’t come home, I mean, they didn’t let us know where he 1s, nothing. And we had a friend, a good friend of the family, he was like dealing with the NKVD all the time, you know, trying to — you know, to [indecipherable] the money, to help people out, or whatever. So we went to him, and maybe he could find out where my brother 1s. And he did find out he was in jail. My father begged him see what he could do. And he promised, you know, for money, of course. And that time they kept him a whole night [indecipherable] we went home. We lived in a zimlanka(ph), you know what a zi-zimlanka(ph) is?

segments.question: No.
segments.answer: It’s made from mud, like a little — little thing from mud. It had one room. This was already in [indecipherable] were liberated. So my brother slept — 1t’s me, my mother and my father, we went to this person to see what he could do. After we came home, my brother slept so hard that no matter what we did — we knocked on Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas ~ May 5, 2013 the window, we knocked on the door, we knocked on the everything and he couldn’t wake up.

segments.question: This is the bro — he was released then?
segments.answer: And — no, not yet.

segments.question: No, this is your younger brother?
segments.answer: This was my middle brother, yeah, the one who worked on the shoes. We couldn’t wake him up, we didn’t know — this was almost wintertime. So my father broke a window, and we got in through the window. It was [indecipherable] I mean, this was the height of the zimlanka(ph), and the zimlanka(ph) — and the window was from here, up to here, like the little window, we climbed in. And he doesn’t know why he couldn’t wake up, he — he — we — we woke him up, we thought he’s — something happened to him. And the next day my brother was freed, he came home. And he’s — and he continued working in the factory, but he never brought home a — a shell of coconut any more.

segments.question: Did he ever talk about what happened in the prison?
segments.answer: Excuse me?

segments.question: Did he ever say what the NK VD asked or did to him?
segments.answer: No, they didn’t — they — they just kept him overnight, they didn’t — why did he steal, or maybe they ask him, he said it’s for my family, they don’t have what to Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas “" May 5, 2013 eat, you know, maybe he said that. But my brother never talked. He was a very quiet man.

segments.question: It sounds like —
segments.answer: He was too good. He didn’t want to hurt anybody.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: So, and then he got this job with my father.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: So he worked until we were liberated in 1945. We were told that we could go home, back to Poland. This was after the war. And of course after the war it was — I was finishing up my seventh grade, which was a big deal at that time. And in March of ’46, we were already in Poland, the whole family, also [indecipherable] hot, it was more comfortable.

segments.question: What had happened to your grandfather? You said that —
segments.answer: To what?

segments.question: Your grandfather?
segments.answer: My grandfather passed away in Troitsk.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: Yeah, in the middle of the war. We buried him there.

segments.question: Okay. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas " May 5, 2013
segments.answer: There was a Jewish cemetery. My father’s father.

segments.question: Did he live in that zimlanka(ph) with you?
segments.answer: He lived with — with my aunt, uncle and her three kids.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: He lived, and they had one room. With — he didn’t live in the zimlanka(ph), no, we did. But later my mother found a room, one room, so we lived in one room. This was already a palace, one room with three beds, my brother slept with another [indecipherable] she was also from the — you know, from us, from our Jewish people. And we slept six people in one room, we had three beds.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: So I slept with my mother, and my older brother slept with the [indecipherable] and my middle brother slept with my father [indecipherable] bed maybe this — this width.

segments.question: Oh my gosh.
segments.answer: But that was already a palace, you know. We had — we were able to get a package from Poland with rice, which the rabbi said you could eat rice on Pesach. My mother was making matzos at somebody’s house, under — under the watchful eye of the NK VD because the judges were upstairs and the oven was downstairs in the same house. But somehow we survived with potatoes, you know, and laid Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas °* May 5, 2013 around, and we were happy to get back to Poland. We never went back to our home. We never back to Rozwadow.

segments.question: Why not?
segments.answer: We — our train stopped in Brandenburg, which is called [indecipherable] in Polish now. And right away the organization started to try to get, you know, the people being organized, like my parents joined the Mizrachi again, with Betas, we were all the — and didn’t stay long. At least I didn’t stay long. I was the youngest of the family. At that time Ralph Herzog was the chief rabbi of Palestine. He came to Poland and gathered 600 young children, and the English promised them 600 certificates to be able to bring to Israel. So he came, and his son. He was the chief rabbi, later on, of Israel. And he — his son was the president of Israel later — later on, when Israel was established. And he took 600 children from the Mizrachi and from the Aguda.

segments.question: Uh-huh. What’s Aguda?
segments.answer: And they still — another religious organization.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: And he gathered them on the — in Katowice in Poland. I went, my cousin, my younger cousin, all three of us were chosen from the Mizrachi, because we were the youngest. And much, much younger children, up to 16 - 17 years. And they Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas “ May 5, 2013 took us to Katowice and [indecipherable] and we were traveling to Czechoslovakia. Supposedly in Czechoslovakia, he is supposed to get the certificates for the kids to go into Palestine, that time Palestine. This was 1946. But certificates never came. We came to [indecipherable] which is now part of — not part of Czechoslovakia, and we stayed there over Shabbas because he didn’t travel Shabbas. The people there brought us food. They divided us in different hotels. We stayed over Shabbas, Shabbas night we went to Prague. In Prague there was a camp for the children, you know, not far from Prague, which was called Jablitz(ph).

segments.question: Jablitz(ph).
segments.answer: [indecipherable] Jablitz(ph). And he left us there, and Rabbi Ralph Herzog and his son went back to Israel, to Palestine that time, to request why he didn’t get the promised cer —

segments.question: Certificates.
segments.answer: — you know, affidavits or certificate. And we never were able to go to Palestine. They left us in Jablitz(ph) and the Aliyah [indecipherable] took over, another Jewish organization, and then divided us into two groups, which were the Mizrachi and Aguda. They took us, after six weeks being in Czechoslovakia, they took us to Strasbourg in France, and Aguda they took to Cassada(ph), which is on the Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas “ May 5, 2013 Spanish border in France. And in France already, we had Madrafeme(ph), which were organizing the kids; the younger kids, the older kids, the middle kids. And we stayed in France from 1946 to 1948.

segments.question: You were with your brother?
segments.answer: We were in France. Strasbourg, and I was in Paris, and I was in Roazhon, different places.

segments.question: But no school at this time, or were —
segments.answer: Excuse me?

segments.question: — were you going to school of some kind?
segments.answer: Yes, in — in Strasbourg, yes, we went to learn French and also we learn — they te — they taught us to sew. You know, it’s [indecipherable] this school. Mostly — not the regular school, but the French school, just to learn French.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Which we learned, of course, and then you forget it, if you don’t use it. So after I found out my father passed away in 1948, in Salzburg, they also emigrated from Poland to — to Austria, to the camps in Austria. I — my father was working with the po — with the Polish council for me to come back to be with them together. Because we couldn’t go to Israel, there was no Israel that time, and the kids who went to [indecipherable] were turned back — Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas °° May 5, 2013

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: — and they couldn’t make it. So my father worked I should legally be able to leave France and come to Austria and be with them. But by the time the papers were ready, he had passed away in March of 1948. By the time [indecipherable] was, and my brother had joined th-the illegal geose(ph), this is the Israeli army, which was illegal one. My oldest brother, he joined with his oldest cousin. After he joined, of course, he went to fight. They went to Italy, first in France, Italy. From Italy they went by boat, by little boat, and they got into Palestine. And he was fighting in 1948 for Israel. I have a picture with his rifle [indecipherable]. They took them off the boat, they gave them rifles [indecipherable]. No exercise, no nothing. He didn’t know how to use a rifle, but that’s what it was. And then I met my husband in 1948, he was from the ma — through a friend.

segments.question: Strasbourg? In Strasbourg”?
segments.answer: No, no, in [indecipherable] Salzburg.

segments.question: In Salz —
segments.answer: In Austria.

segments.question: So you had gone back, you —
segments.answer: I was gone back finally.

segments.question: — you had gone back. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas "° May 5, 2013
segments.answer: In June I was gone back.

segments.question: So your father died in March and —
segments.answer: Yes, and in June I was gone back and I had all the papers ready and everything. I already — my oldest brother, like I said, had really gone to geose(ph).

segments.question: And your youngest?
segments.answer: And only my mother and my little brother were still in Salzburg.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: I stayed with them until I got married.

segments.question: And you met your — you met your future —
segments.answer: Husband through a friend of mine, Joseph Jonas.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: We were going out for years and then we got married. In 1950, we got — we were on the American zone. They did — when they were closing the camps, because our camp was in the city —

segments.question: What was the —
segments.answer: — Bradenburg(ph) was in Salzburg but in the city.

segments.question: What was its name?
segments.answer: It was a camp fo-for soldiers, you know? So they were liquidated and they had to put the people someplace. So some people went to Israel, some people went to Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas "" May 5, 2013 America, some people went to Canada. And my husband’s family, they wanted to go to America because they had family here. My father-in-law had family here, so he registered for America. He didn’t have any papers. Because we were on the American zone, they had to let you go where you wanted, because supposedly you are an American already. So when we came here, we got the green card right away, and the minute we got off the bus — the ship — the ship was coming here was like half dead. We came here on military ships. I remember the name of the ship was General Blatchford. And we almost drowned, it was in December. We came in 1950, in December — 1950, just a day before Christmas.

segments.question: So tell me, why did you almost drown, and why was it half dead?
segments.answer: Because it was that — it was — don’t forget, it wasn’t Atlantic, it was the Pacific, and it’s very rough. The ship was rolling. It was a military ship, you know. It wasn’t a big boat. It was a boat.

segments.question: You were going on the Pacific Ocean?
segments.answer: On a military ship.

segments.question: No, I know, but you were on the Pacific Ocean, not the Atlantic Ocean?
segments.answer: We were on the Atlantic Ocean coming to here.

segments.question: You were on the Atlantic Ocean?
segments.answer: Yeah. Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas "° May 5, 2013

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: But in that time was December. It was like, you know, the storms, the winds, the — it was very scary. So we came here and of course they s — HIAS took over, they settled us in — in a hotel, some of them in HIAS, wherever they had place.

segments.question: I want to ask a few things.
segments.answer: Mm’?

segments.question: One of the reas — why was it that you never went back to Rozwadow? What was the reason for that?
segments.answer: Why I went back what?

segments.question: Why, when you came from Russia to Poland, why is it that you never went back to Rozwadow?
segments.answer: To the city where we came from?

segments.question: Where you — yeah, yeah.
segments.answer: There was nobody left. There were no Jews, only Polacks, and my father never wanted to see the place he was born.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: There was nothing there. All the Jews were brought in to that area, which was occupied by Germany before the war, but after the war they gave it back to Poland, which was Brandenburg [indecipherable] a few cities. And that’s where Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas ”" May 5, 2013 they brought all — 1f somebody wanted to go back, nobody did go back. And then when the riots started, in Brandenburg and in other cities, there were a lot of riots, a lot of Jews killed, then everybody decided to leave Poland. Nobody went back to their own city any more.

segments.question: When did you find out?
segments.answer: We even had killings early in 1946, after the war.

segments.question: What kind of killings?
segments.answer: The — the riots from the Polish anti-Semitin.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: And when did you find out of what had happened to the Jews in Poland?
segments.answer: Excuse me?

segments.question: When did you find out of what had happened to the Jews who remained in Poland? Did you know about that when you already returned?
segments.answer: Yes. My father had a friend who joined the Polish army.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: And he wrote to us where — while we were still in Russia, before we left, he wrote to us what happened to the city, to the Jews, to everything. And he wrote us — that’s my father’s brother’s son, who was alive, he was that time [indecipherable] Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas ” May 5, 2013 when the war s — excuse me — when the war started. And he heard from the goyim he knew, that my uncle’s, my Benny’s son Joseph is alive and he’s now five years old or six, and he’s in Lublin. The gathered all the kids they knew who are Jewish and they could find them, they brought them to Lublin —

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: —1n Poland. And that’s — and that’s how we knew this, what happened. And when you came home, you found out more.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: But we knew in the last — in the beginning not so much — in the last few years we knew what was going on. We knew that my uncle was killed, my aunt was killed, her father was killed. All the family from my father’s, the sisters, the children, the husbands. All my family from my mother’s side, whoever was left in Poland. Nobody survived. Only the only cousin survived. He was a baby and the parents gave him to Polacks, of course for a lot of money, and they — after the war they just said go, go, and some of the Jews picked him up and they brought him to Lublin. And then he came here to this country with his sisters, his mother’s sister, his mother’s father. I mean, they came, he was — I don’t know how — how old he was, maybe five, six years old. He grew up in this country already.

segments.question: Yeah. Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas m May 5, 2013
segments.answer: And he was very, very [indecipherable] the only cousin I have from the family who survived from Germany. Nobody survived from my father’s side, or my mother’s side. They were all killed [indecipherable] killed in the same town where we were crossing the San.

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: They were in Justkowicz(ph), they made — I have a cousin who — it’s not a cousin actually, she’s part of the family like from grandmother’s side. And she — she knew everything what was going on because she was with them, but she survived. She saw how my uncles were shot, everybody in one grave, the sons and everything, the children, everybody put to one grave. As a matter of fact, they have a Polack who takes care of the cemetery in Justkowicz(ph) and [indecipherable], another little village. They send the money every year, the people from here who survived, and they take care of the —

segments.question: That place.
segments.answer: — graves.

segments.question: Those graves
segments.answer: After so many years. So this was my story til I came to Austria.

segments.question: I have a— a couple of other questions. You s — Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Goldie Buch Jonas " May 5, 2013
segments.answer: After we came to — when I married, then after we came to this country, it wasn’t easy. We came without the language, without a penny. After two weeks I found a job. I found a job working in a factory. That time was — we were in Korea, I think, or — yeah, in Korea. I was working for the Eisenhower jackets, you know, in a factory for many, many months until my Moshe was born. We lived in a furnished by somebody in — in a one room apartment.
